title: Section C
passagesOne: Questions 46 to 50 are based on the following passage.

questionsOne.Statement: What can we learn about marriage vows from the passage?

Options.text: They may not guarantee a lasting marriage.
They are as binding as they used to be.
They are not taken seriously any more.
They may help couples tide over hard times.

questionsOne.Statement: What did Karraker and co-author Kenzie Latham find about elderly husbands?

Options.text: They are generally not good at taking care of themselves.
They can become increasingly vulnerable to serious illnesses.
They can develop different kinds of illnesses just like their wives.
They are more likely to contract serious illnesses than their wives.

questionsOne.Statement: What does Karraker say about women who fall ill?

Options.text: They are more likely to be widowed.
They are more likely to get divorced.
They are less likely to receive good care.
They are less likely to bother their spouses.

questionsOne.Statement: Why is it more difficult for men to take care of their sick spouses according to Karraker?

Options.text: They are more accustomed to receiving care.
They find it more important to make money for the family.
They think it more urgent to fulfill their social obligations.
They expect society to do more of the job.

questionsOne.Statement: What does Karraker think is also important?

Options.text: Reducing marital stress on wives.
Stabilizing old couples’ relations.
Providing extra care for divorced women.
Making men pay for their wives’ health costs.

passagesTwo: Questions 51 to 55 are based on the following passage.

questionsTwo.Statement: How might people often feel when they were misnamed?

Options.text: Unwanted.
Unhappy.
Confused.
Indifferent.

questionsTwo.Statement: What did David Rubin’s research find about mis-naming?

Options.text: It is related to the way our memories work.
It is a possible indicator of a faulty memory.
It occurs mostly between kids and their friends.
It often causes misunderstandings among people.

questionsTwo.Statement: What is most likely the cause of misnaming?

Options.text: Similar personality traits.
Similar spellings of names.
Similar physical appearance.
Similar pronunciation of names.

questionsTwo.Statement: What did the surveys of more than 1,700 subjects find about misnaming?

Options.text: It more often than not hurts relationships.
It hardly occurs across gender boundaries.
It is most frequently found in extended families.
It most often occurs within a relationship group.

questionsTwo.Statement: Why do mothers misname their children more often than fathers?

Options.text: They suffer more frustrations.
They become worn out more often.
They communicate more with their children.
They generally take on more work at home.
